text: Hiroyuki Muto. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Muto H (2025). pwranova: Power Analysis Flexible ANOVA Designs Related Tests. R package version 1.0.0, https://github.com/mutopsy/pwranova.
code: @Manual{,   title = {pwranova: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests},   author = {Hiroyuki Muto},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://github.com/mutopsy/pwranova}, }

what: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: pwranova R package power analysis ANOVA designs, including -, within-, mixed-factor designs, full support main effects interactions across number factors. package allows calculation statistical power, required total sample size, significance level, minimal detectable effect sizes expressed partial eta squared Cohen’s f ANOVA terms planned contrasts. addition, complementary functions included common related tests t-tests correlation tests, making package convenient toolkit power analysis experimental psychology related fields.

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: Documentation: https://mutopsy.github.io/pwranova Source code: https://github.com/mutopsy/pwranova

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: can install pwranova GitHub using devtools:
code: # Install devtools if not already installed if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("devtools") }  # Install pwranova devtools::install_github("mutopsy/pwranova")

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: R (>= 4.1.0) heavy external dependencies required core functionality.

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
code: library(pwranova)  ### 1) Compute power (given N, effect size, alpha)  # One between factor (3 levels), no within factor res_power_between <- pwranova(   nlevels_b = 3,   n_total   = 60,   cohensf   = 0.25,   alpha     = 0.05 ) res_power_between  # One within factor (4 levels), no between factor # (Optionally set epsilon for sphericity correction; default is 1) res_power_within <- pwranova(   nlevels_w = 4,   n_total   = 30,   cohensf   = 0.50,   alpha     = 0.05,   epsilon   = 1.00 ) res_power_within  # Mixed design: one between factor (2 levels) and two within factors (2 and 3 levels) # Show only a selected term with `target` if you want a compact output res_power_mixed <- pwranova(   nlevels_b = 2,   nlevels_w = c(2, 3),   n_total   = 30,   cohensf   = 0.50,   alpha     = 0.05,   epsilon   = 1.00,   target    = "B1:W2"  # show only 2x3 interaction of the between factor and the second within factor  ) res_power_mixed  ### 2) Solve required total N (given target power)  # One between factor (3 levels), no within factor res_n_between <- pwranova(   nlevels_b = 3,   cohensf   = 0.25,   alpha     = 0.05,   power     = 0.80 ) res_n_between  # returns the smallest total N (multiple of groups) meeting the target power  ### 3) Planned contrast power  # Contrast weights must sum to 0 res_contrast <- pwrcontrast(   weight  = c(1, -1, 0),  # three conditions, compare 1 vs 2   paired  = FALSE,   n_total = 60,   cohensf = 0.25,   alpha   = 0.05 ) res_contrast

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: Current functions include: pwranova() — Power analysis -/within-/mixed-factor ANOVA, covering main effects interactions. pwrcontrast() — Power analysis single planned contrast (1 df) -subjects paired/repeated-measures designs. pwrttest() — Power analysis t-tests (one-sample, paired, two-sample). pwrcortest() — Power analysis Pearson’s correlation (using either t-distribution Fisher’s z-transformation approach). full documentation, see reference site (pkgdown): https://mutopsy.github.io/pwranova/reference/

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: See Changelog: https://mutopsy.github.io/pwranova/news/

title: Power Analysis of Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: GPL-3

what: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: Converts Cohen's f partial eta squared (\(\eta_p^2\)) using standard definition Cohen (1988).

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: f numeric vector Cohen's f values. value must greater equal 0.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: numeric vector partial eta squared values.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: conversion defined : $$\eta_p^2 = \frac{f^2}{1 + f^2}$$ follows relationship: \(f = \sqrt{\eta_p^2 / (1 - \eta_p^2)}\)

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
code: # Convert a single Cohen's f value cohensf_to_peta2(0.25) #> [1] 0.05882353  # Convert multiple values cohensf_to_peta2(c(0.1, 0.25, 0.4)) #> [1] 0.00990099 0.05882353 0.13793103

what: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: Converts partial eta squared (\(\eta_p^2\)) Cohen's f using standard definition Cohen (1988).

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: peta2 numeric vector partial eta squared values. value must within range 0 1.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: numeric vector Cohen's f values.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: conversion defined : $$f = \sqrt{\eta_p^2 / (1 - \eta_p^2)}$$ follows inverse relationship: $$\eta_p^2 = \frac{f^2}{1 + f^2}$$

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
code: # Convert a single partial eta squared value peta2_to_cohensf(0.06) #> [1] 0.2526456  # Convert multiple values peta2_to_cohensf(c(0.01, 0.06, 0.14)) #> [1] 0.1005038 0.2526456 0.4034733

what: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Computes power, required total sample size, alpha, minimal detectable effect size fixed-effects terms -/within-/mixed-factor ANOVA designs.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
code: pwranova(   nlevels_b = NULL,   nlevels_w = NULL,   n_total = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   cohensf = NULL,   peta2 = NULL,   epsilon = 1,   target = NULL,   max_nfactor = 6,   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: nlevels_b Integer scalar vector. Numbers levels -subjects factors. Omit set NULL -subjects factor. nlevels_w Integer scalar vector. Numbers levels within-subjects factors. Omit set NULL within-subjects factor. n_total Integer scalar vector. Total sample size across groups. NULL, function solves n_total. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved . power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved achieve power. cohensf Numeric (non-negative). Cohen's \(f\). NULL, derived peta2 available. effect-size arguments (cohensf peta2) NULL, effect size treated unknown solved given n_total, alpha, power. peta2 Numeric \((0,1)\). Partial eta squared. NULL, derived cohensf available. epsilon Numeric \((0,1]\). Nonsphericity parameter applied within-subjects terms \(\mathrm{df}_1 \ge 2\). Ignored within-subjects factor within factors two levels. target Character vector term labels compute (e.g., "B1", "W1", "B1:W1", ...). NULL, terms returned. max_nfactor Integer. Safety cap total number factors. nlim Integer length-2. Search range total n solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: data frame S3 class: "cal_power" power calculated given n_total, alpha, effect size; "cal_n" "cal_ns" n_total solved; "cal_alpha" "cal_alphas" alpha solved; "cal_es" minimal detectable effect sizes solved. Columns include term, df_num, df_denom, n_total, alpha, power, cohensf, peta2, F_critical, ncp, epsilon.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Fixed-effects, balanced designs assumed. groups/cells equal cell sizes effects tested standard fixed-effects ANOVA models. Numerator degrees freedom within-subjects terms \(\mathrm{df}_1 \ge 2\) adjusted nonsphericity parameter epsilon. Denominator degrees freedom follow standard mixed-ANOVA formulas multiplied epsilon within-subjects terms. Critical values computed central F-distribution; power uses noncentral F-distribution noncentrality parameter \(\lambda = f^2 \cdot n_{\mathrm{total}}\). Effect-size inputs can given Cohen’s \(f\) partial eta-squared \(\eta_p^2\) (internally converted via \(f = \sqrt{\eta_p^2/(1-\eta_p^2)}\)). NULL, minimal detectable effect size solved given n_total, alpha, power. Exactly one n_total, effect-size specification (cohensf/peta2), alpha, power must NULL; quantity solved. Validation GPower: subset designs supported GPower (-, within-, mixed-factor ANOVA equal cell sizes), pwranova() validated produce results identical GPower.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
code: # One between factor (k = 3), one within factor (m = 4), compute power pwranova(nlevels_b = 3, nlevels_w = 4, n_total = 60,          cohensf = 0.25, alpha = 0.05, power = NULL, epsilon = 0.8) #>    term df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power cohensf      peta2 F_critical #> 1    B1    2.0     57.0      60  0.05 0.3744311    0.25 0.05882353   3.158843 #> 2    W1    2.4    136.8      60  0.05 0.3592414    0.25 0.05882353   2.876716 #> 3 B1:W1    4.8    136.8      60  0.05 0.2687648    0.25 0.05882353   2.307783 #>    ncp epsilon #> 1 3.75     1.0 #> 2 3.75     0.8 #> 3 3.75     0.8 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # Solve required total N for target power pwranova(nlevels_b = 2, nlevels_w = NULL, n_total = NULL,          peta2 = 0.06, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8) #>   term df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power   cohensf peta2 F_critical #> 1   B1      1      124     126  0.05 0.8034337 0.2526456  0.06    3.91755 #>        ncp epsilon #> 1 8.042553       1 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.

what: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: Computes power, required total sample size, alpha, minimal detectable effect size single planned contrast (1 df) -participants paired/repeated-measures settings.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
code: pwrcontrast(   weight = NULL,   paired = FALSE,   n_total = NULL,   cohensf = NULL,   peta2 = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: weight Numeric vector (length \(K \ge 2\)). Contrast weights whose sum must zero. paired Logical. FALSE -subjects (default), TRUE paired/repeated-measures. n_total Integer integer vector. Total sample size(s). NULL, function solves n_total. cohensf Numeric (non-negative). Cohen's \(f\). NULL, derived peta2 available. peta2 Numeric \((0,1)\). Partial eta squared. NULL, derived cohensf available. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved . power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved achieve power. nlim Integer length-2. Search range total n solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: one-row data frame class: "cal_power" power calculated given n_total, alpha, effect size; "cal_n" n_total solved; "cal_alpha" alpha solved; "cal_es" minimal detectable effect sizes solved. Columns: term (always "contrast"), weight (comma-separated string), df_num, df_denom, n_total, alpha, power, cohensf, peta2, F_critical, ncp.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: contrast weights \(w_1, \dots, w_K\) sum zero, numerator df 1. denominator df \(n - K\) -subjects (unpaired) designs \((n - 1)(K - 1)\) paired/repeated-measures designs. Power uses noncentral F-\(\lambda = f^2 \cdot n_{\mathrm{total}}\). Contrast weights (weight) centered internally; zero-sum condition enforced (numerical tolerance). paired = FALSE, total sample size n_total must multiple number contrast groups \(K\). Exactly one n_total, effect-size specification (cohensf/peta2), alpha, power must NULL; quantity solved. Critical values computed central F-distribution; power based noncentral F-distribution noncentrality parameter \(\lambda = f^2 \cdot n_{\mathrm{total}}\). Effect-size inputs can given Cohen’s \(f\) partial eta-squared \(\eta_p^2\) (internally converted via \(f = \sqrt{\eta_p^2/(1-\eta_p^2)}\)). NULL, minimal detectable effect size solved given n_total, alpha, power.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
code: # Two-group contrast (1, -1), between-subjects: compute power pwrcontrast(weight = c(1, -1), paired = FALSE,             n_total = 40, cohensf = 0.25, alpha = 0.05) #>       term weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha    power cohensf      peta2 #> 1 contrast   1,-1      1       38      40  0.05 0.337939    0.25 0.05882353 #>   F_critical ncp #> 1   4.098172 2.5 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # Four-level contrast (e.g., Helmert-like), solve required N for target power pwrcontrast(weight = c(3, -1, -1, -1), paired = FALSE,             n_total = NULL, peta2 = 0.06, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80) #>       term     weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power   cohensf peta2 #> 1 contrast 3,-1,-1,-1      1      124     128  0.05 0.8095375 0.2526456  0.06 #>   F_critical      ncp #> 1    3.91755 8.170213 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.  # Paired contrast across K=3 conditions pwrcontrast(weight = c(1, 0, -1), paired = TRUE,             n_total = NULL, cohensf = 0.2, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.9) #>       term weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power cohensf      peta2 #> 1 contrast 1,0,-1      1      526     264  0.05 0.9003788     0.2 0.03846154 #>   F_critical   ncp #> 1   3.859198 10.56 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.

what: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
text: Computes statistical power, required total sample size, \(\alpha\), minimal detectable correlation coefficient Pearson correlation test. Two computational methods supported: exact noncentral t (method = "t") Fisher's z-transformation normal approximation (method = "z").

title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
code: pwrcortest(   alternative = c("two.sided", "one.sided"),   n_total = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   rho = NULL,   method = c("t", "z"),   bias_correction = FALSE,   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
text: alternative Character. Either "two.sided" "one.sided". n_total Integer scalar. Total sample size (\(n\)). Must \(\ge 3\) method = "t" \(\ge 4\) method = "z". NULL, function solves n_total. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved . power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved attain power. rho Numeric correlation coefficient \((-1,1)\), nonzero. NULL, rho solved given inputs. method Character. Either "t" (noncentral t-distribution) "z" (Fisher's z transformation normal approximation). bias_correction Logical. Applies method = "z". TRUE, uses bias-corrected Fisher z-transformation \(z_p = \operatorname{atanh}(r) + r/(2(n-1))\). nlim Integer vector length 2. Search range n_total solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
text: one-row data.frame class "cal_power", "cal_n", "cal_alpha", "cal_es", depending solved quantity. Columns: df (method = "t") n_total, alpha, power rho, t_critical z_critical ncp (noncentrality parameter mean alternative: see Details)

title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
text: Exactly one n_total, rho, alpha, power must NULL; quantity solved. method = "t", computations based noncentral t-distribution noncentrality parameter \(\lambda = \tfrac{\rho}{\sqrt{1-\rho^2}} \sqrt{n}\). method = "z", computations use Fisher's z transformation population correlation, \(z_\rho = \operatorname{atanh}(\rho)\). Let \(W = \sqrt{n-3}\, z\). alternative hypothesis, \(W \sim \mathrm{Normal}(\mu,\,1)\) \(\mu = \sqrt{n-3}\, z_\rho\). bias_correction = TRUE, \(\rho\) first bias-corrected applying Fisher's transform. Critical values taken central normal distribution \(H_0:\rho=0\) (.e., \(W \sim \mathrm{Normal}(0,1)\) null). returned ncp equals \(\mu\). Validation GPower: Results confirmed match produced GPower equivalent correlation tests using noncentral t-distribution. Note: Results method = "z" exactly match pwr::pwr.r.test, pwr uses hybrid approach combining Fisher-z approximation t-based critical value.

title: Power Analysis for Pearson Correlation — pwrcortest
code: # (1) Compute power for rho = 0.3, N = 50, two-sided test pwrcortest(alternative = "two.sided", n_total = 50, rho = 0.3, alpha = 0.05) #>   df n_total alpha     power rho t_critical      ncp #> 1 48      50  0.05 0.5867505 0.3   2.010635 2.223748 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # (2) Solve required N for target power, using Fisher-z method pwrcortest(method = "z", rho = 0.2, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8) #>   n_total alpha     power rho z_critical     ncp #> 1     194  0.05 0.8000666 0.2   1.959964 2.80182 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.  # (3) Solve minimal detectable correlation pwrcortest(n_total = 60, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.9, rho = NULL) #>   df n_total alpha power       rho t_critical      ncp #> 1 58      60  0.05   0.9 0.3915971   2.001717 3.296573 #> The minimal detectable Cohen's f and partial eta squared were calculated based on the total sample size, alpha, and power.

what: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
text: Computes statistical power, required total sample size, \(\alpha\), minimal detectable effect size t-test one three designs: one-sample, two-sample (independent), paired/repeated measures.

title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
code: pwrttest(   paired = FALSE,   onesample = FALSE,   n_total = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   delta = NULL,   cohensf = NULL,   peta2 = NULL,   alternative = c("two.sided", "one.sided"),   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
text: paired Logical. FALSE two-sample (independent; default), TRUE paired/repeated-measures. Ignored onesample = TRUE. onesample Logical. TRUE one-sample t-test; TRUE, paired ignored. n_total Integer scalar. Total sample size. NULL, function solves n_total. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved given inputs. power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved attain power. delta Numeric (non-negative). Cohen's \(d\)-type effect size. NULL, derived cohensf peta2 available. three effect-size arguments (delta, cohensf, peta2) NULL, effect size treated unknown quantity solved given n_total, alpha, power. exact definition depends design: One-sample: Cohen's \(d = (\mu - \mu_0)/\sigma\). Paired: Cohen's \(d_z = \bar{d}/s_d\), .e., mean difference scores divided standard deviation. Two-sample (equal allocation): Cohen's \(d\) defined mean difference divided pooled standard deviation; internally related \(f\) via \(d = 2f\). NULL, delta derived cohensf peta2 available. cohensf Numeric (non-negative). Cohen's \(f\). NULL, can derived delta; delta supplied, cohensf ignored. Effect-size relations design: Two-sample (equal allocation): \(d = 2f\) Paired: \(d_z = f\) One-sample: \(f\) \(\eta_p^2\) supported peta2 Numeric \((0,1)\). Partial eta squared. NULL, can derived cohensf; delta supplied, peta2 ignored. defined one-sample designs. alternative Character. Either "two.sided" "one.sided". nlim Integer vector length 2. Search range total n solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
text: one-row data.frame class "cal_power", "cal_n", "cal_alpha", "cal_es", depending solved quantity. Columns: df, n_total, alpha, power, delta, cohensf, peta2, t_critical, ncp.

title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
text: multiple effect-size arguments supplied (delta, cohensf, peta2), precedence delta \(>\) cohensf \(>\) peta2; rest ignored warning. two-sample design, equal allocation assumed; n_total must even provided, solved n_total even number. paired design, effect size interpreted \(d_z\). Computations use central noncentral t-distributions (stats::qt, stats::pt); root finding uses stats::uniroot() needed. Results validated match produced G*Power equivalent one-sample, paired, two-sample t tests.

title: Power Analysis for One-/Two-Sample and Paired t Tests — pwrttest
code: # (1) Two-sample (independent), compute power given N and d pwrttest(paired = FALSE, onesample = FALSE, alternative = "two.sided",          n_total = 128, delta = 0.50, alpha = 0.05) #>    df n_total alpha     power delta cohensf      peta2 t_critical      ncp #> 1 126     128  0.05 0.8014596   0.5    0.25 0.05882353   1.978971 2.828427 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # (2) Paired t-test, solve required N for target power pwrttest(paired = TRUE, onesample = FALSE, alternative = "one.sided",          n_total = NULL, delta = 0.40, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.90) #>   df n_total alpha     power delta_z cohensf    peta2 t_critical      ncp #> 1 54      55  0.05 0.9004524     0.4     0.4 0.137931   1.673565 2.966479 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.  # (3) One-sample t-test, solve alpha given N and power pwrttest(onesample = TRUE, alternative = "two.sided",          n_total = 40, delta = 0.40, alpha = NULL, power = 0.80) #>   df n_total     alpha power delta cohensf peta2 t_critical      ncp #> 1 39      40 0.1001708   0.8   0.4      NA    NA   1.683997 2.529822 #> Alpha was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and power.  # (4) Two-sample, specify effect via f or partial eta^2 (converted internally) pwrttest(paired = FALSE, cohensf = 0.25, n_total = NULL, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80) #>    df n_total alpha     power delta cohensf      peta2 t_critical      ncp #> 1 126     128  0.05 0.8014596   0.5    0.25 0.05882353   1.978971 2.828427 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.

title: pwranova 1.0.0 (2025-09-28)
text: First stable release package. Provides power analysis functions : -, within-, mixed-factor ANOVA designs (main effects interactions). Planned contrasts user-defined weights. t-tests (one-sample, paired, two-sample). Pearson correlations (using either t-distribution Fisher’s z-transformation). Supports solving : Statistical power Required total sample size Significance level (alpha) Minimal detectable effect size (Cohen’s f, partial eta squared, Cohen’s d-type indices). Validated G*Power supported ANOVA designs, t-tests, correlation tests.
